Javhlan used to make and sell saddles but gave up the business because of low income. In 2010 she began to sell clothing with her sister and now she sells clothing at a local market. Her daily income is 15,000 to 20,000 MNT and her monthly gross income is 300,000 MNT. Now she has inventory valued at 600,000 MNT. 

Javhlan is a hardworking and modest person who says, "I am working to have my own stall in the future so that I can save money on rent and expand my business." She is requesting a loan of 350,000 MNT to purchase more clothing that she can sell at her rented stall.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida is 49-years old, married and supports her family by operating 2 business ventures:  buying & selling dried fish and operating a tricycle transport business.  She lives in Narra, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her buying & selling of dried fish and tricycle transport businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000. Nida is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she could purchase more stocks to sell.  

 This will be her 21st loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Nida aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Bayarsaihan

texts.en:
Bayarsaihan, 42, is married and lives with his wife and two children in Suhbaatar province of Mongolia. His wife is a kindergarden teacher and his older son attends college while younger son goes to a local secondary school. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they own. 

Bayarsaihan started a transportation service business in 1992 with a Russian truck. Now he transports coal between local towns in the winter time. In the summer time he transports different shipments depending on the availability. Bayarsaihan is a hardworking and honest person who says, " I am planning to build a house on the land that I own by next year".

He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT since he is going to buy a new car.

loans.use: To buy a new car

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 42-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store, buying and selling peanuts. and operating a livestock business. She lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, buying and selling peanuts and operating her livestock businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 2,800. 

Mary is borrowing PHP 12,000 so that she could purchase more stocks to sell. This will be her 3rd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Mary aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference  in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team."

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is a 56-year old single woman who supports her family by operating a business venture: buying & selling ready to wear clothing. She lives in Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. Delia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 9 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Delia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 30000, which she intends to use as additional capital so that she could continue to save up for the future to improve living conditions. Delia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:
 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Provide additional working capital

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is a 32-year old single woman who supports her family by operating a grocery store and an electronic loading business.  She lives in Narra, Palawan. Cristina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cristina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy more stocks for the grocery store so that she could expand into produce business. Cristina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:
 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference  in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.use: Purchase more stocks for her grocery store

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona is a married woman who lives in Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a fish vending business. Her husband, Alberto, who is 42 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are between 11 and 17 years old. 

Chona joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Chona has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 18,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $239 a month, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 12th cycle loan, she is borrowing 20,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for sending her children to school in the future. Chona is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Ma. Gilda

texts.en:
Ma. Gilda is a married woman who lives in Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a business of buying, weaving and selling nipa (a palm whose foliage is used for thatching). Her husband, Bennymar, who is 30 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are between 4 and 8 years old. 

Ma. Gilda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 6,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $75, raising the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing 10,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Ma. Gilda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more supplies for her business

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg, 51, is married and lives with her husband and elderly father in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband is unemployed and helps her with the cafe business, which they started in 2010. Before starting the cafe she worked as a tailor for a clothing shop. They opened their cafe by using their own working capital. At the beginning the cafe business was slow but now they have regular customers and the business has expanded compared to the beginning. 

Oyunchimeg is a very neat and polite person who says, "We are trying to expand our cafe and open a restaurant in the future." She is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to buy equipment and food for their cafe.

loans.use: To buy equipment and food for the cafe

loans.name: Edna's Group

texts.en:
Edna B. is from the village of Calamagui 1st. She is 56 years old and the group leader of a twelve-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Edna B.'s Group.

Edna is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately $74 a month for these activities.

In 2004, Edna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Edna is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 13th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Leticia's Group

texts.en:
Leticia F. is from the village of San Jose Santiago. She is 46 years old and the group leader of a fifteen-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Leticia F.'s group.

Leticia is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over nineteen years and earns approximately $138 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Leticia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn C. is from the village of Olango, Mallig, Isabela. She is 49 years old. Marlyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests rice to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over eighteen years and earns approximately $933 per harvest.

In 2008, Marlyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 26,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Marlyn is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be her 6th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Nop

texts.en:
Nop S. is a businesswoman who has been operating her own small business for years. She sells vegetables, fresh fish, and other meats in her community in Kompong Cham province. She was married, but she has been divorced from her husband for many years, and now lives with her three single children. She typically earns an average income of $3 each day to use for the whole family.

Currently, she always needs to hire a taxi to deliver her items to her selling place because she has no vehicle. Nop S. is taking out her loan to buy a used motorcycle which will be used to transport her goods, and the rest of fund will be used to buy more vegetables, fresh fish, and meats to sell.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle to transport her goods, and to buy more vegetables, fresh fish, and meats to sell.

loans.name: Phorng

texts.en: Phorng M., age 32, has been earning a daily profit by making the equipment for woman to cook food. She usually generates an income of approximately $0.75 a day. She has a life partner in her husband who climbs palm trees around his village, in Kompong Tom province. Palm-tree-climbing jobs are very popular jobs for poor people who live in the community. The couple is blessed with two single children who are still learning in school.  Presently, she and her family live in the old house that often needs repair. Some parts her house are breaking and growing rotten wood, so it is not comfortable for her and her family to live in. To solve this problem, Phorng M. would like to buy some poles for repairing the broken parts of her house.

loans.use: To buy some poles for repairing the broken parts of her house.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta C. is from the village of Olango. She is 48 years old. Loreta is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests rice to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-nine years and earns approximately $1057 every harvest season.

In 2008, Loreta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 31,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Loreta is requesting a new loan of 33,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be her 6th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a married woman who lives in Toledo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures. She is an Avon dealer and she also sells ready to wear clothing.  Her husband, Godofredo, who is 47 years old, works as a porter to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 19 and 21 years old. 

Erlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 11,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $135, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 5th cycle loan, she is borrowing 11,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase items and goods for her business so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her businesses. Erlinda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is a 36-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: buying and selling of livestock and vegetable vending business. She lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her livestock and vegetable vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,000. 

Rosa is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she  could fund her business operations. This will be her 3rd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rosa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the  Dungganon way.

loans.name: 03-Dong Son Group

texts.en:
Ai N. T.  is a 40 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Ai is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 03-Dong Son (10.11.03 Dong Son).

Ai is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, Ai owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a tailoring business.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members.  Ai has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3.000.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2011, Ai joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ai is requesting for the first time, a loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.   She is now requesting a loan of 4248000 VND which will be used to purchase a new sewing machine.  Ai plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  N. T. Thuy (13) is a 23 year-old woman who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a fishing business.

2.  T. T. Hoa (14) is a 40 year-old woman who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

3.  L. T. Xuan (15) is a 50 year-old woman who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

4.  L. T. Tu (16) is a 46 year-old woman who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Thin

texts.en:
Living in the province of Kompong Chhnang, Thin M., a 47 year-old married woman  tries to earn a living by cultivating crops on her own farmland. She and her husband have spent most their life time farming. They grow rice crop following the rainy season and the dry season. The couple has received great success from their farming business year after year. 

Thin M. has five single children, and one who is married. Two of them are working in different occupation to earn incomes. Her daughter works in the garment factory and has no vehicle to ride to her job location. When she needs to go to work, she has to rent a motor taxi. To resolve this problem, Thin M. is requesting a Kiva loan for her daughter to purchase a motorbike to ride to her place of work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her daughter to ride to work.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia D. is from the village of Tinagaan, Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Sonia is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Sonia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily daily use products such as shampoo, soap, snacks, canned goods & toothpaste in the local community. Sonia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sonia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Sonia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

texts.en:
Soperiana is a widow who lives in Moises Padilla, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a sari-sari (general) store. She has 9 children who are 28 to 41 years old.  Soperiana joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1996 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Soperiana has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 which she intends to use to buy stocks for her general store so that she could continue to save up for future business expansion.  Soperiana is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:  
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: 02-Dong Son Group

texts.en:
Khuyen H. T. K. is a 31 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Khuyen is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 02-Dong Son (10-02-02 Dong Son).

Khuyen is married and has 1 infant-aged child.  To making a living, Khuyen operates a family member's business venture in the services sector operating a transportation service.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing transportation services to local community members.  Khuyen has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3.000.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, Khuyen joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Khuyen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.248.000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business.  

She is now requesting a new loan of 5.787.900 VND which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business.  The loan will be the 10th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khuyen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  N. T. Huong (5) is a 44 year-old woman who is requesting a 5787900 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

2.  V. T. Toan (2) is a 48 year-old woman who is requesting a 5787900 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

3.  N. T. Hang (4) is a 61 year-old woman who is requesting a 5787900 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a service-based business.

4.  N. T. Hoe (6) is a 48 year-old woman who is requesting a 5787900 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a service-based business.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

Han N. T. (9) là 56 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Han là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 01 Dong Hai (10.01.01 Dong Hai).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ thịt heo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Han thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Han kiếm được khoảng 3,000,000 VND.  Vào 2004, Han đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Han đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4,248,000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 8th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

5.  LeT. Luong (21) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5787900 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marina's Group

texts.en:
Marina P. is from the village of Divisoria Sur Maddela Quirino. She is 56 years old. Marina is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marina P..

Marina is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Marina owns and operates a fruit-selling business. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Marina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Marina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Marina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: 02-Dong Hai Group

texts.en:
Tuynh D. T. (227) is a 59- year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Tuynh is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02-Dong Hai (16-05-02-Dong Hai).

Tuynh is married and has four adult children. T. make a living, Tuynh operates a family member's rice farm. Tuynh has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month.

In 2004, Tuynh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women T. gain access T. financial services T. help improve her business and living situation. Tuynh has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used T. purchase fertilizers such as manure. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,787,900 VND which will be used T. purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops T. raise. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Tuynh from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Tuynh plans T. use the additional revenue generated from the business T. improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the other borrowers in the group:
1. L. T. T. Van (54) is a 27-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan T. support her specialized retail store.

2. T. T. Yen (257) is a 34-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan T. support her butcher shop.

3. N. T. Hien (55) is a 29-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan T. support her livestock business.

4. L. T. Dong (17) is a 38-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan T. support her farming business.

5. L. T. Hieu (52) is a 56-year-old woman who is requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan T. support her farming business.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is T. provide sustainabL. financial services T. disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

loans.name: Veang

texts.en:
Veang T., 32, is married to Hung, 35. She and has given birth to four children, all of whom are still young. 

Veang T. is a skilled manicurist and she has run a service of door to door nail decoration in the neighborhood since 2005. She earns a good profit. 

Her husband has been selling meatballs and other snack food for over five years. He runs his business by using a motorbike connected with a cart. Unluckily, his existing motorbike breaks so often that he spends a lot of money repairing it. To deal with this problem, Veang T. would like to request a loan for her husband to purchase a motorcycle to replace the broken one.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to transport products

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Fatima is the leader of this group loan. She resides in a small city in Pakistan named Sahiwal. Sahiwal is known for its agriculture industry. She lives there with her family in a two-room brick house. 

She is a 37-year-old housewife, who stays at home and does her household work. She has great administrative skills and manages her household expenses very well.  

Ghulam Fatima is the mother of three sons and two daughters. Her eldest son is a rickshaw driver and the second one sells fruit salad on a cart. Her remaining children are enrolled in a school and getting their education.
 
Ghulam Fatima is married to R., who runs a Punjabi food restaurant. He has been operating this business for 10 years. He offers his clients Nan chaney (made with chick peas and served with bread), Daal chawal (made with lentils, and served with boiled rice) and other traditional Punjabi food at reasonable rates. Due to the good quality and good taste of his food, he handles a good number of clients at his restaurant.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy required ingredients such as cooking oil, rice, lentils, spices and chickpeas to make good food for selling.
  
Ghulam Fatima is hopeful that her husband’s business will grow more by investing loan money into it, and that that will result in a better standard of living for her family.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy required ingredients for restaurant business

loans.name: Khot

texts.en:
Khot K. is an  older mother blessed with six children, all of whom are single. To help the family, two of her children are working in Malay. Khot K. raises many pigs and rice crops on her own land next to her house inKompong Tom province. She receives help from her husband in this business operation.

 Because the pig raising business is a very profitable one for Khot K. and her family, Khot K. has requested a loan in order to buy additional piglets to raise to sell during the period when pork is commanding the highest price.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets to raise for sale.

loans.name: Reun

texts.en:
Mrs. Reun S. is married with four children. She has been living in a commune located in Siem Reap Province. She and her husband earn a profit by fishing in a local lake and river which provides them with enough fish for their family. Mrs. Reun S. always wakes up early in the morning to go fishing and is back home in the evening time. Mrs. Reun S. then sells the fish that she has caught in the lake from her store located in her house. 

As fishing is the family's core source of income, Mrs. Reun S. is asking for a loan of $400 USD to buy more fishing equipment, such as nets and traps, to expand her fishing business.

loans.use: To buy more fishing equipment, such as nets and traps, to expand her fishing business.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel D. is from the village of Tinagaan, Salay, Misamis Oriental. He is 31 years old. Joel is separated from spouse and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Joel owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling wood and coco charcoals in the local community. He is also engaging in retailing business. Joel has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Joel is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional wood & coconut shell for charcoal making & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Joel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the  business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional wood & coconut shells for charcoal making & to provide working capital

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen A. is from the town of San Francisco. She is 25 years old. Aileen is married and has 3 children aged 6, 4 and 2. To make a living, Aileen owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Aileen is working hard to build her business and be able to save for her children's future.

Aileen joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aileen is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Aileen from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

texts.en:
Oliva S. is from the village of Tinagaan, Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Oliva is separated from spouse and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Oliva owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. Oliva has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Oliva joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Oliva has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Oliva is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk foods. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Oliva from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice to sell. loans.name: Joey

texts.en:
Joey S. is from the village of San Isidro, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. He is 47 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Joey buys and sells green and yellow bananas in the local community. Joey has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

Joey has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. loans.name: Expedito

texts.en:
Expedito L. is from the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. He is 30 years old. Expedito is married and has four school-age children. To make a living, Expedito owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling seafood products, including fish like sardines and milk fish, in the local community. Expedito has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. He is also engaged in retailing business, as his wife is in charge in the store. Expedito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Expedito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Expedito is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like mackerel and salmon. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Expedito from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

He also works as a mechanic so as to supplement his income. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has developed a culture of saving.  He has also learnt how to plan for his business.  He hopes to become a successful businessman in the future.  He has requested 50,000 Kes to buy rice, sugar, milk and cooking fat.

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Antonieta does her best to provide for the needs of her family. 

Antonieta joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has been in this business for the last three years and makes a monthly income of 20,000 KES. He is taking out his second loan from KADET LTD after successfully repaying his first loan without default. 

Kennedy will use his loan to buy a stock of household items to sell. He will use his anticipated profits to pay back his loan and also to feed his family. His dreams and desires are to expand and open a retail shop in a permanent spot as opposed to his open-air location. He is hoping that Kiva lenders will help make his dream a reality.

She hopes to expand her business and establish a hairdressing college in the future. Akashi want to use this 40,000 KES loan to purchase manicure equipment and a hair dryer. She decided to join Yehu because of the variety of helpful products provided.

loans.name: The Nusrat Tariq Waheed Group

texts.en:
Nusrat is 45 years old. She is married to T. W., who runs a jewelry selling business in the market. The couple has two daughters and both are enrolled in the local school to get an education. The eldest is 17 years old. Nusrat lives in Sahiwal, which is famous for its cows and agriculture industry. For the past 20 years, she has lived there in a two-room brick house with her family. Nusrat is a housewife and she prefers to stay at home and complete her household responsibilities. She is a very active lady and performs her duties very well. 

Nusrat has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner Asasah to expand her husband’s jewelry business. With the loan, her husband will buy jewelry, such as rings, earrings, necklaces and bangles, in larger quantities to increase his business variety and boost sales. Nusrat’s husband started this business six years ago and Nusrat is hopeful that a loan investment will increase profits so she will be able to start saving money for her elder daughter’s marriage. 

In the photo, Nusrat is holding the blue Asasah Passbook. She is a new loan applicant with Asasah and is hopeful that this loan will increase her profits.

loans.use: to buy jewelry to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth Adhiambo

texts.en:
Elizabeth Adhiambo L. is a 53 a year old lady from Kolwa, a remote agricultural area of Kisumu City. She is married to Philip L. and they have five children.

Elizabeth runs a farming business in Kolwa where she plants maize, vegetables, and beans to sell and also for home use. She has been doing this for the last year. The farm is able to earn her a monthly income of 10,000 KES. She is requesting her second loan from KADET LTD to buy maize seeds for planting, fertilizer, and also to pay for labor costs for the people she will hire to assist her with tilling the land.

Elizabeth’s dream is to have a big maize plantation from which she will be able to harvest maize in bulk and supply to different learning institutions within Kisumu City.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Gelem

texts.ru:
Gelem H. 47 let. Ona razvelas s mujem i ne imeyet detey. Gelem yavlyayetsya IDP personom ona preselenec iz Kalbadjar regiona, seychas projivayet v Absheron regione vmeste so svoyey mamoy i sestroy. 
Gelem ranshe rabotala uchitelniccey v shkole no potom ona otkrila svoy servisniy centre. Seychas ona 1 qod kak nachala zanimatsya chasno s detmi i pripodovat im Fiziku. Eto uje yeyo vtoraya ssuda,  perviy raz ona brala 1200$ i za etu ssudu ona ochen blagodarna vsem lenderam i Kive, Gelem seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit knigi i testi kotoriye stoyat doroga i deti ne imeyut vozmojnosti pokupat ix. Gelem ochen lubit svoyu rabotu. Ona userdno rabotayet chto bi soderjat svoyu semyu tak kak yeyo mama uje pojelaya i silno boleyet.

http://partners.kiva.org/lend/5392
texts.en:
Gelem H. is 47 years old. She is divorced, without children. Gelem is an Internally Displaced person from the Kalbadjar Region, now living in the Absheron Region together with her mother and sister. Gelem used to work as a school teacher, but later she opened her own office. For a year she has been giving private physics tutorials to children. This is her second loan; the first time she took out $1200. She is very grateful to all lenders and to Kiva. At present Gelem needs 2000 AZN in order to buy books and tests, which are expensive, and children cannot afford them. Gelem loves her work. She works very hard to support her family as her aging mother  is ailing.

http://partners.kiva.org/lend/5392

loans.use: Purchasing necessary books and tests
