She opened her business after saving 150,000 shillings while working in farming. Babra is happily married, has three children and makes about 600,000 shillings a month in her current line of work. She is a member of the Kisimba Women's Group-Lugazi and she says she will use her portion of this group loan to improve her business by buying better fishing nets.

loans.use: The purchase of better fishing nets

loans.name: Dalmas

texts.en: Dalmas is 32 years old, married, has three children and makes a living selling fish. He has been in business for 10 years, has four employees, and reports that his business peaks daily in the morning.  He supplements his income by renting out houses, and has felt very financially empowered since joining Faulu Kenya, which has helped him grow his business. His goal is to continue expanding his small company, and he is applying for this loan for 80,000 Kes to buy more fish to sell to his customers

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell to his customers

loans.name: Amgalan

texts.en: Amgalan is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Suhbaatar province of Mongolia in a ger, or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, which is pitched on a friend's property. His oldest child attends university while the other two live at home. He earns a living making boots with his wife. Since 2000, they have concentrated on making traditional Mongolian Buryat boots. Amgalan also works as a secretary during meetings in his county. He is very friendly and is applying for this loan for 600,000 MNT to buy more materials to use in making boots.

loans.use: To buy more materials to use in making traditional Mongolian boots

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina E. is 27 years old and lives in the town of Banga. She is married, has four young children and makes a living by planting and harvesting rice. Her main goal is to save for her children's future, so she can provide them with a good education.

Dina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She successfully repaid her first loan and is applying for a new one, for 8,000 PHP, to buy fertilizer and other supplies. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to pay for her children's tuition. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training through regular group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Chhi's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four low-income people who live in Siem Reap province. Chhi T., age 41, has been chosen as leader of the group. She is divorced, has three children and makes a living by selling fish. She earns a profit of about $2 a day and will use her portion of this loan to buy more fish to sell. 

There are three other people in this loan group: 
Mrs. T. makes a living fishing and will use her portion of this loan to buy more equipment.
Mrs. K. will use this loan to buy a used motorbike in order to replace a one.
Mrs. R. is applying for a loan to buy equipment which will allow her to catch more fish.

loans.use: To help expand four small businesses.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert, aged 25 years, is a married man living in a semi-permanent house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. Five years ago he sold his goats and got initial capital. He deals in buying and selling coffee and maize. He dreams of educating his children, building a permanent house, and having a permanent farm. Robert wants a loan to buy coffee and maize for resale.

loans.use: Buying coffee and maize for resale

loans.name: Enhbayar

texts.en:
Enhbayar, 48, is married and lives with his wife and a daughter in Suhbaatar province, Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in someone's backyard. They have a house but they have not purchased their own land yet. His daughter attends college. 

In 2005 Enhbayar began to sell meat at a local market where he rents a stall. His wife helps him with the meat business. Enhbayar is a hardworking and good-mannered person who says, " I want to help my daughter to finish her studies and become a well-educated person in the future." He is requesting a loan of 200,000 MNT to purchase more meat for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en:
Emelda is 55 years old, married, and supports her family by operating two business ventures: buying and selling crabs and shrimp and buying and selling "nipa" (palm thatch). She lives in Ilog, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1995 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4000. Emelda is now borrowing PHP 27,000 for additional capital for her business.  This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 21,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Emelda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem has been living in Sahiwal for many years with her family in a 2-room brick house. Sahiwal is a small city in Pakistan, known for its agriculture and cattle farming. She is 37 years of age and has given birth to three sons and a daughter. Only one of her children is able to attend school and get an education. Her husband’s name is M. R. and he operates a wheat and rice-selling business. He uses his four-wheeled cart to sell to different areas of the community. 
 
Naseem herself is a seamstress. In order to help her husband financially, she sews clothes for her neighboring clients. She is very good in her work and receives regular orders every month. She is also a very good housewife and carries out her household responsibilities effectively. 
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will replace the old wheels of his cart with new wheels and continue operating his business.  Naseem is confident that an investment in her husband’s business will be a good step towards its growth and he will be able to provide better living conditions to the family as a result.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible client and never missed a single meeting.

loans.use: To replace the old wheels of their four-wheeled cart

loans.name: Kamugenyi Tweyambe Group

texts.en: Lawrence, aged 50 years, is a married man living in a semi-permanent house in Kyenjojo,Uganda. He has been a retailer for the last nine years. He dreams of building a permanent house and putting up a diary farm. He wants a loan to buy more sugar, salt and rice for resale.

loans.use: Buying more sugar, rice and salt for resale

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a married man with one child, who is still young for school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and food for the family.

He has operated a vegetable stall for the past two years, selling retail and from home to his neighbours and passersby. In addition he also operates a boda boda (motorcycle transport) business which is his other source of income. Daniel faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes to continue to have more than one business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to start a water selling business. He decided to join Yehu because of its efficiency of loans.

loans.use: To start a water selling business

loans.name: Martin

texts.en: Martin is 37 years old, married and blessed with two children who go to school.  For eleven years, he has been selling vehicle spare parts so as to earn a living.  So far, he has employed two people.  Martin was previously employed in butchery and opted to go into a different business so as to earn better income.  He hopes to have a stable business in five years.  With the loan of 50,000 Kes, he will buy engine parts and suspension parts.

loans.use: To buy engine parts and suspension parts

loans.name: Aliseni

texts.en: Forty-seven-year-old Aliseni would like a loan to buy beans and posho (cornmeal) to supply a school. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda in a semi-permanent house. He desires to have a self-sustaining family.

loans.use: Purchase beans and posho (cornmeal) to supply a school

loans.name: Violet

texts.en: Violet is a thirty-nine-year-old mother with six children .She wants a loan to buy cosmetics and hair extensions for resale. She runs a salon in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. She dreams of expanding her business, educating her children, and having a modal home.

loans.use: Buying  cosmetics and hair extensions for resale

loans.name: Misandika S&c Group

texts.en: Amos would like a loan to purchase sugar, rice, radio batteries, and soap for resale. He runs a retail shop. He is a married man with ten children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He dreams of educating his children up to university level and making his family self-sustainable. He is a member of Misandika Savings and Credit group where each member guarantees the other in accessing credit.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, rice, radio batteries and soap for resale

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en: Sylivia is twenty-five years old and a single mother with two children, owning a house in Kasese, Uganda. Her hardship is bad debtors and her vision is business expansion. Sylivia needs the loan to buy clothes for resale.

loans.use: Buying clothes for resale

loans.name: Dulia

texts.en:
Dulia is a farmer living in the town of Banga with her family. She owns and tills her own land where she plants and harvests rice crops. Dulia sells her rice to the traders. Dulia has many plans for her family. One of those is to improve their house in order to have a better shelter.

Dulia works hard to earn a living from her farm. She currently needs fertilizers and other inputs. She is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP which she will use to buy the farm supplies she needs.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying charcoal for resale

loans.name: Philip Ekipetot

texts.en:
Philip Ekipetot T. is 54 years old, married, and a father of four children.  He and his family live in the town of Lodwar.  Philip runs a retail shop where he sells fast-moving items such as sugar, milk, and rice. He has been in this business for nine years and earns a monthly income of 18,500 Kenyan shillings (KES).

This will be Philip's first loan from KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to buy inventory for his business. He plans to use the income he will generate to diversify his business and to buy a goat for further sale.

In the future, Philip wants to be a successful businessman in Lodwar.

loans.use: To buy inventory such as rice, sugar, and cooking fat

loans.name: Lavinah

texts.en: Lavinah is a twenty-five-year-old married woman with two children, renting a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been dealing in hardware and the drug shop business for two years. She started with a small drug shop and as it expanded, she started a hardware business. Her hardship is debtors, price fluctuation and thieves. Her vision is a pharmacy and a well stocked hardware shop plus a wealthy family. Lavinah needs the money to buy medical drugs, cement, iron sheets and nails for resale.

loans.use: Purchasing drugs, cement, iron sheets and nails

loans.name: Dynamique Group

texts.fr: M’Lwamira P.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire Dynamique, âgée de 50 ans, mariée, mère de 3 enfants qui étudient a l’université. Son M. est un enseignant.la cliente  M’Lwamira P. est  vendeuse des divers (bâches, couvertures, etc.). Elle s’installe au long de la Rue, au point de vente de l’entrée du quartier Katindo II-Katoyi. Elle démarra son activité avec un fonds propre reçu de sa fille ainée. Il ya 3 ans qu’elle est en activité. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouvelles marchandises (1 ballon de bâches, 1 carton d’huile végétale, farine masoso, 1 ballon de couverture, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise, passer le reste de sa vie en paix. La cliente M’Lwamira Pelagie remercie Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe bora est constitué de 29 membres.
texts.en: M’Lwamira P. is an entrepreneur and president of the Dynamique business group.  She is 50 years old, married, and mother of 3 children who attend university.  Her husband is a teacher. M’Lwamira P. is a seller of various items (tarpaulins, blankets, etc.) She sets up along the Road, at the retail area at the entrance of the Katindo Il-Katoyi neighborhood.  She started her business with funds received from her eldest daughter.  She has been in business for 3 years.  This new loan will help her stock up on new merchandise (1 ball of tarpaulin, 1 carton of vegetable oil, Masoso flour, 1 ball of blankets, etc.)  In addition, she aspires to grow her business, and spend the rest of her life in peace. M’Lwamira P. thanks Hakima for their work dedicated to poor women excluded by traditional banks. The Bora group consists of 29 members.

loans.use: 1 ball of tarpaulin, 1 carton of vegetable oil, Masoso flour, 1 ball of blankets, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Delgersaihan

texts.en:
Delgersaihan, 44, is married and lives with his wife and two daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. They live in a house where they have lived for 18 years so far. His wife works as a cook for a cafe and his two daughters attend local secondary school. 

Delgersaihan began a wooden-product making business in 1994. All his family members support his business and now his business has become more stable. In the beginning, he started his business with a working  capital of 50,000 MNT and now it exceeds 580,000 MNT. He is a hard-working and modest person who says,"I am trying to expand my business and save money for my daughters' future studies. I want them to become well-educated people." He is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to purchase more wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood

loans.name: Kengele

texts.en: Kengele is a forty-seven-year-old married man with seven children, owning a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been a butcher for twelve years;  he started by buying cattle and selling to butchers, but now he has his own butcher shop. His hardship is competition with fish sellers plus price fluctuation and  his vision is opening another butcher business in the municipality and having a well-educated family. Kengele needs the loan to buy goats for slaughter.

loans.use: Buying goats for slaughter

loans.name: Jones

texts.en:
Jones is a married man with two children, one of whom attends school while one is too young for school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are school fees.

He has operated an electronics shop for the past seven years, doing business in a shop to his neighboring community. Jones faces a major challenge of rationing of electricity and fluctuation of prices of goods. He hopes to expand his business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase spare parts for his electronics shop. He decided to join Yehu because of the efficiency of its loans.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his electronics shop

loans.name: Enecita

texts.en:
Enecita, 41 years old, is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 3 children aged 14, 20, and 24. To make a living, Enecita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Enecita works hard to ensure healthy crops and a productive rice farm.

Enecita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Enecita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Enecita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to buy fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a twenty-five-year-old married man, renting a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the transport business for two years starting with a bicycle. He now has a motorcycle. His hardship is difficulty riding during the rainy season and his vision is to get another motorcycle and build his own house. Julius intends to use the loan to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: Buying a motorcycle

loans.name: Surriya's Group

texts.en:
Surriya resides in a city called Sahiwal in Pakistan. Sahiwal is famous for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a two-room brick house with her family since her marriage. She is 49 years old, an active lady who operates her sewing business at her home to supplement the income of her family. She works for community clients who give her regular orders every month due to her good quality services. 

Besides her sewing work, Surriya actively manages her household responsibilities and makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family. Her husband’s name is M. S.. He is a rickshaw driver and provides transport services to his passengers. She has given birth to six sons: three of them work while two are studying and the youngest one who is eight years old stays at home.
 
Surriya has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine because her old machine doesn’t produce quality work and takes much time to sew a single dress.  She hopes that a loan investment will benefit her sewing business to a great extent. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In previous loan years, she has always paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Surriya.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for sewing business

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en:
Narantuya, 52, is widowed and lives with her three children in Suhbaatar province, Mongolia. They live in an apartment and her youngest daughter attends college. She began selling cosmetics in 2005 and her oldest daughter helps her with the business. They are distributors of the brand "Oriflame", a popular Swedish cosmetic manufacturer. They work very hard for the company and make commissions from their sales. Her daughter takes orders from their customers and sends the list to the branch office through the internet. 

Narantuya has become a reliable and certified member of the company and she receives different bonuses in addition to her commissions. She is a hard-working and brave person who says, "I now earn money and support my family thanks to this business and  I want to increase my customer base which will give me more orders." She is requesting a loan of 900,000 MNT to purchase some more cosmetics to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying  poultry feed

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a thirty-nine-year-old married woman with five children, owning a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been dealing in agricultural produce for the last ten years starting with ten bags of coffee but later increasing to three hundred bags. Her hardship is high transport costs and her vision is increased business capital plus educating her children. Grace needs the loan to buy bags of maize and cotton for resale.

loans.use: Buying  bags of maize and cotton for resale

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza C. is from the village of Malandog, Rogongon, Iligan City. She is 35 years old. Analiza is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Analiza owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. Analiza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Analiza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analiza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Analiza is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Analiza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods

location.town: Malandog, Rogongon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: 5 Nam Ngan Group

texts.en:
Tu N. T. (23) is a 42-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh H..  Tu is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 5 Nam Ngan (02.06.1.5 Nam Ngạn).


Tu is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Tu owns & operates a tailoring business.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing general  alteration & tailoring services to local community members.  Tu has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2011, Tu joined Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Tu is requesting  a loan from Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women for the first time.    She is now requesting a new loan of 4,248,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women.  Tu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. T. Ha (24) is a 38-year-old woman who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food.


2.  V. T. Ngoc (25) is a 52-year-old woman who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her general store.


3.  L. T. D. H. (26) is a 35-year-old woman who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her tailoring business.


4.  L. T. H. (27) is a 34-year-old woman who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her food stall.


5.  N. T. Su (28) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her food stall.


6.  L. T. Thuc (29) is a 65-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


7.  D. T. H. (30) is a 41-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her service-based business.


About Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh H. Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh H. province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Tu N. T. (23) là 42 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh H..  Tu là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 8 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 5 Nam Ngan (02.06.1.5 Nam Ngạn).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ may vá quần áo thông thường cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Tu thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Tu kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2011, Tu đã tham gia Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Tu đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.248.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Ha (24) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  V. T. Ngoc (25) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


3.  L. T. D. H. (26) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc.


4.  L. T. H. (27) là 34 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


5.  N. T. Su (28) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


6.  L. T. Thuc (29) là 65 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


7.  D. T. H. (30) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


Về Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  D. việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac is a sixty-year-old married man with nine children, owning house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the bar business for nine years starting with one jerrycan of local brew plus one crate of beer. He now buys more than five crates. His hardship is seasonal customers and his vision is business expansion plus educating his children. Isaac wants the loan to buy drinks and repair his fridge.

loans.use: Buying drinks and repairing his fridge

loans.name: Orm

texts.en: Orm N. is a 51-year-old married woman who has been living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Tom province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents where she grows rice and vegetables. She has no life partner because she divorced her husband when her daughter was young. Her daughter is a cashier in the Siem Reap province and needs a vehicle to drive to work, but she lacks the money to buy one. Therefore, Orm N. wants a loan from Kiva to buy a used motorcycle so her daughter can get to work.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle for her daughter to get to work

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia S. is from the village of Rogongon, Iligan City. She is 49 years old and married with seven adult children. To make a living, Lilia owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and toothpaste. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month. 

In 2010, Lilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Lilia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Rogongon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a single woman who owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

Rehema has operated a tailoring business for the past two years, selling in a shop to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major business challenge in the high cost of transportation. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase more bundles of clothing materials and embroideries. She decided to join Yehu because of the efficiency of their loans products.

loans.use: To  purchase bundles of clothing materials and embroideries.

loans.name: Oltitiyio Ole

texts.en:
Oltitiyio Ole S. is a 35-year-old farmer. He is married and a father of three children. He has been farming his own piece of land for the last five years.
  
Oltitiyio learned about KADET LTD from a member of a group in his area that is registered with KADET. This will be his second loan, and he plans to use it to buy maize seed, fertilizer, and other chemicals required for the farm. He plans to re-invest profits from the proceeds of the loan in the farm and to plant more acres of maize.

His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and be able to buy his own farm machinery.

loans.use: To buy maize seed, fertilizer, and other farm chemicals

loans.name: Beth

texts.en: Beth is a thirty-one year old single mother with two children living in Kyenjojo Uganda. She is a salary earner. She wants to have a good life and better education. Beth wants a loan to pay her tuition.

loans.use: Pay her tuition fees

loans.name: Ma. Remie

texts.en:
Ma. Remie is 35-years old and married and supports her family by operating a motorcycle transport business. She lives in Carcar, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Ma. Remie is borrowing PHP 12,000 so that she can purchase tools and equipment. This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ma. Remie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase tools and equipment

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine A. is from the village of Malandog, Rogongon, Iligan City. She is 32 years old. Josephine is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods & toothpaste in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk foods. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Malandog, Rogongon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is a beautician. She is a married lady with two children who go to school.  She has been running her salon for seven years.  She has seen a lot of growth in her business since she joined Faulu Kenya.  She has employed one person in her business.  She hopes to open other outlets for her business in the future.  She needs 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a hair dryer and cosmetics.

loans.use: To buy a hair dryer and cosmetics

loans.name: Astone

texts.en: Astone lives in the district of Kyenjojo in Uganda and is longing to build a permanent house and educate his children. He is a retail trader and has been in business for five years. This has enabled him to pay school fees for his children. His vision is to become a wholesale trader. Astone needs the loan to buy maize and beans to sell.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
Hazel M. is from the town of Banga. She is 29 years old. Hazel is married and has three children aged 4, 6 and 8. To make a living, Hazel owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Hazel works hard to provide for her family's needs and save up for her children's education.

Hazel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hazel has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Hazel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is a 33-year-old single woman who supports her family by operating one business venture: buying and selling firewood. She lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. Alma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Alma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.

 Her previous loan of PHP 8000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing PHP 16,000, which she intends to use to purchase more firewood to sell so that she can continue to save up for future for her child and family needs. Alma is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Namulesa Twekembe Group-Lugazi

texts.en: 33-year-old N. Diana is a member of the Namulesa Twekembe group-Lugazi. She has been involved in a tailoring business for close to 14 years now in Nagunga-Lugazi. She says she began this enterprise 14 years ago. Before that the happily married mother of four was doing farming. Monthly she says this business generates shillings 120,000, and with this loan, she says she is going to buy more textiles for making clothing.

loans.use: The purchase of more textiles to make clothing

loans.name: Buyanravjih

texts.en: Buyanravjih, 49, is married and lives with her husband and three children and a nephew in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Her older daughter attends college and one of her children has health problems. She used to operate a dairy products trading business which she started in 2005; she began a vegetable trading business in 2008. She plants vegetables in her backyard and sells them at the market. From 2010, she began planting uncommon vegetables such as tomatoes, chilis, and cucumbers in addition to common vegetables. She is requesting a loan of 700,000 MNT to purchase some more vegetables that she can sell at her stall.

loans.use: To purchase some more vegetables

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is a single woman who owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

She has operated a retail shop for the past nine months; her potential customers are local residents. Lillian faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation of commodities. She hopes to expand her business to a wholesale one in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase sacks of sugar, salt, tea leaves, cooking oil and detergent. She decided to join Yehu because of the availability of loan products that meet her needs.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar, salt, tea leaves, cooking oil and detergent

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en:
Nieves F. is from the village of Kabacsanan, Iligan City. She is 49 years old. Nieves is widowed and has eight adult children. To make a living, Nieves owns & operates a mini-restaurant serving a variety of different meals like adobo & afritada to customers in the local community. Nieves has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Nieves joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nieves has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. Nieves is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients like meat & vegetables & working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Nieves from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

location.town: Kabacsanan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a married woman who lives in Rizal, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a general store and a piggery business.  Her husband Nickarter, who is 47 years old, works as a solar collector to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are between 10 and 25 years old. Erlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Erlinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,700, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use to buy more stock so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Erlinda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen J. is from the town of Banga. She is 52 years old. Helen is married and has two children aged 25 and 22. To make a living, Helen owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Helen wishes for her family to be happy and healthy always.

Helen joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Helen is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to buy additional fertilizer and seeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.name: Bon Berger Group

texts.fr: Kabuo J.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire Bon Berger, âgée de 34  ans, mariée, mère de 5 enfants. Son marie est un enseignant. La cliente  Kabuo J.  est  vendeuse des denrées alimentaires (tomates, huile de palme, oignons, etc.). Elle s’installe au long de la Route, au point de vente  du quartier Ndosho-CAJED. Elle démarra son activité avec un fonds propre reçu de son mari ayant une valeur de 60$. Il ya 3 ans qu’elle est en activité. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouveaux produits (4 bidons d’huile de palme, 1 bidon d’huile végétale Rina, 1 sac d’oignons, 2 paniers de tomates, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise, scolariser ses enfants et construire confortablement sa maison. La cliente Kabuo J.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Bon Berger est constitué de 28 membres.
texts.en:
J. Kabuo is an entrepreneur and president of the business group Bon Berger (good shepherd) which consists of 28 members. She is 34 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a teacher. 

J. Kabuo sells foodstuffs (tomatoes, palm oil, onions, etc.). She sets up by the road in the commercial area of the Ndosho-CAJED district. She started this activity with her own capital of $60 received from her husband. She has been in business for three years. 

This new loan will allow her to replenish her stock of products (four cans of palm oil, one can of Rina vegetable oil, one bag of onions, two baskets of tomatoes, etc.).  She also plans to expand her business, give her children and education, and build a comfortable home. 

J. Kabuo wishes to thank Hekima for helping the less fortunate women who cannot turn to traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy 4 cans of palm oil, 1 can of Rina vegetable oil, 1 bag of onions, 2 baskets of tomatoes, etc.

texts.en:
33-year-old Jemelyn C. lives in the town of Banga with her family. She is married and has two children aged 14 and 9. Jemelyn grows pigs and plants rice crops. She maintains a small backyard piggery and tills a rice farm with her husband. Jemelyn also spends time running a sari-sari store. She sells biscuits, sugar and other products. Jemelyn works hard to provide for her family.

Jemelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jemelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jemelyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to buy farm inputs and pig feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie O. is from the village of Cabalantian, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Tessie is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing "motorela" or "habal-habal" motorcycle transport services (with her husband as the driver) to local community members. She also buys and sells fish like sardines & milk fish. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase tools needed to expand services provided. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the transport service. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Tessie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for maintenance

loans.name: Bebeth Isabel

texts.en:
Bebeth is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  jewelry and goldsmith businesses.  Her husband Robert, who is 44 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are between 7 and 21 years old. 

Bebeth Isabel joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Bebeth Isabel has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use to buy jewelry and raw materials for her business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Bebeth Isabel is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Welma is a 40-year-old married woman who supports her family by buying and selling firewood.  She lives in Compostela, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Welma is borrowing PHP 16,000 so that she can purchase a new tool for her business.   This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Welma aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita O. is from the village of Cabantian, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Teresita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2002, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 18th loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Nou

texts.en: Nou Y. is 62 and the mother of one single kid. Nou Y. is a local farmer who has been planting a variety of crops since 1981. She has no life partner in her husband as he died of senility. She also relies on income from her son’s work. He sells bread. He normally orders a large amount of bread at a reasonable cost and then sells his product to his regular clients when they make an order. Her son makes an income from this business of around $10 a day to help support Nou Y. with her daily expenses. Recently, he has planned to buy new clothes for resale in order to make extra income in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. This is the reason that Nou Y. has requested a loan of $1,200 from Kiva.

loans.use: To buy new clothes for her son to sell.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida, who is 44-years old and married, supports her family by operating two business ventures: a general store and a farming enterprise. A resident of Narra, Palawan, Nida has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable, and now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,000.

Nida is requesting her second loan for PHP 10,000 to purchase more stocks to sell. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Nida aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Sofronio

texts.en:
Sofronio U. is from the village of Poblacion, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. He is 46 years old. Sofronio is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Sofronio owns & operates a business providing general repair services like vulcanizing of tires to local community members. Sofronio has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sofronio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sofronio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. Sofronio is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Sofronio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees.

She has operated an ice cream selling business for over two years, selling from home to school children. Florence's major challenge is seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase a deep freezer for storing ice cream for sale. She decided to join Yehu because of its loan efficiency.

loans.use: To purchase a deep freezer for storing ice cream for sale.

Maria Fe is a 52-year old married woman supporting her family by operating three business ventures: a general store, a vegetable-vending operation, and a gasoline retail business. A resident of Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental, Maria Fe has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable, and now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4000.

For her third loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Maria Fe is borrowing PHP 15000 in order to purchase more stocks to sell. Her previous loan of PHP 7000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Maria Fe aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Razel

texts.en:
Razel M. is from the village of Tuod, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years old. Razel is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Razel owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. She also buys and sells green & yellow bananas, "ube" & vegetables like cabbage. Razel has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Razel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Razel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Razel is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & bananas. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Razel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

texts.en: Twenty-nine-year-old Robert would like a loan to cultivate land. He has been a maize farmer for the last four years and his dream is having a food store. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda in a semi-permanent house. His desire  is to put up a permanent house and educate his children.

loans.use: Cultivating land

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn C. is from the town of Banga. She is 50 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Jocelyn dreams of having a stable business.

Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  farming and buying & selling dried fish. Her husband Samuel C., who is 51 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 14 and  23 years old. 

Elena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Elena has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow, making an income from the sales of products from her farm. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy fertilizers such as manure so that she can continue to save up for future improvement of business. Elena is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

Hellen is a single woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees.

She has operated a business selling building materials for the last eight years, selling from home to her neighbors and orders from house builders. Hellen's major challenge is seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business and sell at wholesale in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase ballast. She decided to join Yehu because of the variety of loans that meets the customer’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase ballast.

loans.name: Somian

texts.en:
Somian O. K. is 42 years old. He is married, and he is the father of eight children. Somian is a businessman, and he runs a retail shop on a rental premise in Narok, which he has been doing for the last eleven years.

He learned about KADET from KADET staff through their marketing efforts. This will be his second loan, and he is planning to buy more stock for his retail shop. His business is doing well in the area due to its strategic location at the center.

With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to expand his business into a wholesale shop. His hope and dream is to become a prominent businessman.

loans.use: To buy more stock for his retail shop, including rice, sugar, and maize flour

loans.name: Tadeo

texts.en: Forty-two-year-old Tadeo would like a loan to buy sugar, salt and rice to sell. He has a retail shop and has been in this business for three years. With the profits, he has been able to pay school fees for his children. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda in a rented house and he hopes to become a wholesaler, build a permanent house and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy sugar,salt and rice to sell

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia is a 58-year-old widow who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  a general store and buying & selling rice.  She lives in Narra, Palawan. Rosalia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosalia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to buy stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future improvement of her business. Rosalia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg

texts.en:
Erdenetsetseg, 43, is widowed and lives with her two children in Suhbaatar province, Mongolia. They live in a two-room apartment that they own. Her older child, a daughter, attends college while her son goes to a local secondary school. Erdentsetseg currently works as a gas station attendant three days a week. When she is off work she makes traditional and modern clothing.

 She started to sell her handmade clothing in 1995. She used to operate her business out of a rented workshop but now she makes clothing at home when she gets custom orders. She is a modest and quiet person who says,  I save some more money to help my son since he has gotten married and started his own life. Therefore, I want to help him to build everything from the beginning." She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase materials for her clothing business.

loans.use: To purchase materials

loans.name: Lemeria

texts.en:
Lemeria O. S. is 51 years old. He is married and the father of ten children. Lemeria is a farmer. He farms his own piece of land, and he has been doing this for the last twelve years.

He learned about KADET LTD from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, and he is planning to buy farming supplies. He hopes to use the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming.

Lemeria's dream is to be a prominent farmer in the region and to ensure his family has a better standard of living. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is a 47-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating one business venture: fish vending. She lives in Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000. Julieta is  borrowing PHP 30,000 so that she  can fund operations. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 30,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Julieta aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Madame  Akouvi  a 27 ans.  Elle fait la coiffure  et a associé la vente des mèches.   Elle  compte dans cette  activité 4 ans d’expériences. Elle a son salon de coiffure  à côté de la  Fucec-Togo  à Akodessewa  et  achète ces nécessaires  au grand marché de Lomé. Son activité lui permet d’améliorer  les  conditions de vie de son enfant. Elle est  mariée et  habite  quartier  Ggenyedzi.  Pour répondre au mieux la demande des clients, elle sollicite  de WAGES un prêt.
texts.en:
.Mrs Akouvi is 27 years old. She has 4 years experience as a hairstylist and sells hair dye products.

She has her hairdressing salon beside Fucec-Togo (a discount supplier) in Akodessewa (a fetish and voodoo market) and buys supplies in the large market of Lome. 

This activity enables her to improve the living conditions of her child. 

She is married and lives Ggenyedzi district. 

To serve her customers better, she requests WAGES a loan

loans.use: to buy beauty salon supplies and dyes.

loans.name: Thiev

texts.en: Thiev P., 41 years old, is a humble villager living in the province of Kompong Tom. She is married and blessed with three single children who still live with Thiev P.. To earn a living, Thiev P. sells many kinds of vegetables, which she either buys in bulk from her supplier or grows. Her husband also helps her to pick up the vegetables in the mobile place for selling. In order to earn extra profit and to make the business more successful, Thiev P. will be using the loan she requested to buy a large quantity of vegetables for selling.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Ma. Leonora

texts.en:
Ma. Leonora D. is from the town of Banga. She is 40 years old. Ma. Leonora is married and has 3 children aged 20, 17 and 16. To make a living, Ma. Leonora owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Ma. Leonora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Ma. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
